captions.text:
Word up, playas. This week on Thug
Notes we kickin it in to beast mode with Beowulf
by...

So. S’all good up in The Land of
the Danes where righteous King Hrothgar dun

built a mead-hall for his army so they can
get white-boy wasted on the reg. Them playas

ragin so hard that they disturb a stank beast
named Grendel, who start rollin up to the

mead-hall erry night to lay a whoop on them
Danes.

Grendel beefin wit them boys for
years til one day Beowulf, the baddest muthafu**a

in the whole world, rolls up to the king and
say that not only is he gonna waste Grendel,
but he gonna show out and do it unarmed.

Hrothgar gets all geeked up about
Beowulf’s arrival and go balls-out to celebrate.

When Grendel finally busts in and starts scrappin
with Beowulf, that scrub aint no match fo

Wolfy, who straight rips his arm off. Then
Grendel cowers back to his spot, where he
bleeds out like a little ol bitch.

Hrothgar gives big ups to Beowulf
for icing Grendel, but the party gotta stop

short when Grendel’s mama gets all crunk
bout her son’s death and start jackin sh**
up in the mead-hall.

So Wolfy and his boys strap up and
head to her underwater crib where Beowulf
straight mercs this beezy.

Now that the Danes be rid of all
they monsters, Beowulf rolls back home to

Geatland where he shares his bling with the
King Hygelac and Queen Hygd.

Later, Hygelac and his son get
shanked in a war, so Beowulf inherits the

throne. After years of rockin the crown like
a boss, old man Beowulf hear some bad news:

his pad got smoked by a dragon. See, some
wank-ass fool boosted a Goblet from the phat

stash of that dragon, and when he realizes
someone been gankin his ice, he start goin
HAM all up Geatland.

Even though he an old geezer now,
Beowulf gathers his posse and steps up to

buck dat dragon. Wit the help of his boy Wiglaf,
Beowulf gats dat scaley scrub, but not before
gettin bitten by his poisonous fangs.

In the end, Beowulf goes belly up
from da poison. So mah boys build a decked

out funeral pyre and send him off with a bunch
of the shiniest bling in the land.

So even though the Geats lost a
badass King, he dun left them with a swoel

fortune. And in a culture of tit for tat,
the king is swingin a big dick when he’s

bank rollin his peeps. Cuz if your pants ain’t
bulging with benjamins, your people ain’t
gonna show you no love.

Like that hater King Heremod, it
don’t matter how much power God givin you,

if you don’t cough up the cash, you only
gonna bring ruin to your people.

Let this marinate, son. When it
comes to layin the anglo-saxon poetry game,

you can bet that the da character names be
loaded with meaning.

So let me tell it like it is:
Homies always debatin bout the meaning of

Beowulf’s name, but the tightest translation
is man-wolf- reppin my boy’s human and beastly
qualities.

Cuz sometimes Beowulf actin chill,
but other times he comin out so hard that

he just as monstorous all those beasties he
beefin wit.

Like dat uber-mayne Nietzche sayin
in Beyond Good and Evil-

But Beowulf’s beef with those
monsters don’t just stop at all dat slangin

and bangin. The realest danger is in becoming
a gnarly beast just like them. Cuz on the

real, Wulfy’s rampagin is just his outta
control pride attempting to solve the violence
of the world with mo’ violence.

Even when Wulfy steps up to
Grendel, his head get way too big when he

gotta show out and wreck Grendel without his
chrome. Although Hrothgar tells him not to
give in to pride, Beowulf don’t listen.

Cuz it’s dat pride that keeps
Beowulf from gathering an posse to bust a
cap in dat dragon.

And its exactly this that leads him to the
greatest monster of all, one

that’s so bad, no baller can touch it no
matter how righteous he thuggin- death.

Yo thanks for watching Thug Notes.
Subscribe, ya heard?

title: Beowulf - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.text:
It`s a folk epic. It was not written by any single author. It was passed 
down from generation to generation with each bard adding or taking 
something away. Then some unnamed bard sorted it out to the point of it 
being a cohesive narrative, an then some monk wrote it down.﻿

comments.author: samiamtheman 73

comments.text:
I think the point is, is that Beowulf carries on the pride of youth into 
his old age. Hrothgar, throughout the poem described as wise, decided that 
after all his men could not face Grendel, he accepted the help of a 
stronger and more youthful warrior. However, after his men cannot face the 
dragon, Beowullf decides that only he can kill the beast, leading to his 
death. It is Beowulf's denial of his own age that is representative of his 
pride. As for the fact that he ruled the Geats for fifty years, Hrothgar 
had a similar reign of prosperity. However, Hrothgar knows better than most 
that in the end, one must accept the ravaging of time, and not let pride 
overshadow wisdom: "O flower of warriors, beware of that trap.
Choose, dear Beowulf, the better part,
eternal rewards. Do not give way to pride.
For a brief while your strength is in bloom
but it fades quickly; and soon there will follow 
illness or the sword to lay you low,
or a sudden fire or surge of water
or jabbing blade or javelin from the air
or repellent age. Your piercing eye
will dim and darken; and death will arrive, 
dear warrior, to sweep you away".
comments.author: Martin Freeman

comments.text:
+Martin Freeman I'm sorry, but I think that it ridiculous to say that 
Beowulf the character suffered fatally from pride and arrogance. He ruled 
the Geats for 50 years of prosperity. He died because everyone has to 
eventually, not due to any faults of his.
comments.author: TrevRockOne

comments.text:
+Pete McKenna The story is very much based around pride and arrogance as 
the greatest failures of a hero. After reading Tolkien's translation, it 
seems apparent that Hrothgar warns Beowulf frequently that pride and 
arrogance lead to complacency, even going as far as to use historical tales 
of previous prideful kings, who's arrogance led them to ruin. As well as 
this, the poem also stresses that a ruler is only a great as his people 
(the king to thane theme), and that going it alone, as Beowulf frequently 
does, is foolish.
comments.author: Martin Freeman

comments.text:

southern most tribes in that migration influenced it as well ya know? Where 
as when I think Scandinavian I think Norway, Northern Denmark, Finland and 
Sweden. Not so much north central Germany, north eastern France, and the 
west coast of Denmark.

I just learned about the monk thing. So he was writing it for a noble?

comments.text:
I did read the whole conversation. And I know that; that's why I said "the 
Germanic tribes who became the Anglo-Saxons". Still, the Saxons who went on 
to help found England came from that North Sea area. England has it's roots 
in the North Sea/Southern Scandinavia area. To make some stark demarcation 
between early Anglo-Saxons and Scandinavians is just silly.
comments.author: TrevRockOne

comments.text:
+TrevRockOne Um... Saxon is the other half of that word. Saxony isn't part 
of the peninsula. That's pretty key. And you should read the full 
conversation. Context is good. Furthermore, there were more tribes than 
just those two that came over in the migrations over to Britain. 
Anglo-Saxon is a catch all term for all the tribes that migrated around the 
same time.
comments.author: fmlAllthetime

comments.text:
+fmlAllthetime You're being a total pedant. The Germanic tribes who became 
the Anglo-Saxons came to Britain from the same Jutland peninsula on which 
Denmark lies. The Anglo-Saxons and Scandinavians shared a common cultural 
heritage.
comments.author: TrevRockOne

yes, but it saves me a lot of time to not deal with rude ass trolls.

I get what you're saying now. That trait specifically was very anglo-saxon. 
That makes more sense. So in the end, the story is a hybrid. It's like a 
Scandinavian body frame for a car, accessorized by the British. That's 
really cool to know sincerely. Most things are hybrids at the end of the 
day though :) , historically speaking that is.

Thank you for giving me a chance and giving such an informative answer. If

hopefully the children don't drive you mad lol.
comments.author: fmlAllthetime

comments.text:
+fmlAllthetime Ok, I see what you are asking, and it makes sense. I don't 
think it invalidates it, but I think we have to look at the bigger 
historical picture to fully understand. Yes, it is based on an original 
Scandinavian tale that was then sung by scops (bards) for a a long, long 
time until a monk wrote it down sometime around the 700's. We really can't 
say with certainty what the bards actually sang, because when the monk 
wrote it down, he added, embellished, and changed things. For example, we 
know that the Norse gods would have been important to Beowulf's people (the 
Geats), but "Beowulf" has a serious amount of Christian allusions. Where 
did that come from? The "author" aka the monk who wrote it down. Thus, he 
took the bones of a Scandinavian story and altered it to fit his own 
culture. We know from other historical pieces what the Anglo-Saxons valued, 
and with that background, we can see things that were probably added or 
altered to appeal to the audience of that time and place, i.e. the 
arrogance of the hero. 
Thanks for the conversation! Sorry if I was curt before-- I work with teens 
all day and thought you were just trying to be argumentative. My apologies.
comments.author: Carla Ingraham

comments.text:
+fmlAllthetime If you don't trust my word (Master's in English plus 24 
years of teaching literature), look it up online. Project Gutenberg (
http://www.gutenberg.org/files/16328/16328-h/16328-h.htm), translations by 
Tolkien, even Wikipedia which isn't the best source but has accurate 
information about the origins and classification of the poem-- they (and 
any university website) all back up its Anglo-Saxon roots.
comments.author: Carla Ingraham

comments.text:
+Carla Ingraham That's not what I was trying to ask. Obviously *Beowulf* 
has strong Scandinavian influences right? It was a Scandinavian story 
originally. Just because someone adds cultural characteristics to the story 
does that change the fundamental nature of that story? Does this invalidate 
the original culture it came from?

Let's put it this way, let's put it in the musical context. Say there are 
two members of a K-Pop group (Korean Pop) that are American, obviously 
American culture will influence the final product and it has (just listened 
to a NPR interview with an American born K-Pop producer). Does this now 
invalidate the qualifier in the genre title?

That's what I'm trying to ask :)

Thank you for taking your time to answer me.
comments.author: fmlAllthetime

comments.text:
+fmlAllthetime It depends on the author and the audience. If American 
values were infused into the story instead of traditional Japanese values 
then it could not be considered Japanese literature. "The Jungle Book" is 
not considered Indian literature, nor is a book set on Mars considered 
Martian literature. Setting does not define type.
comments.author: Carla Ingraham

comments.text:
+Pete McKenna  think it's more apparent in the lines when he introduces 
himself to Hrothgar. 
"Hail Hrothgar!/ ...the days of my youth have been filled with glory..." 
and several lines later, "My people.../Have seen my strength for 
themselves/Have watched me rise from the darkness of war,/ Dripping with my 
enemies blood. I drove/Five great giants into chains.../...I swam/In the 
blackness of night, hunting monsters/Out of the ocean, and killing them 
one/By one..." It's a resume of sorts, and it does show more arrogance than 
we would expect from our heroes. We tend to like the "Gee, it was nothin'-- 
I was just in the right place at the right time" kind of hero and don't 
like egotism; they did.
comments.author: Carla Ingraham

comments.text:
+Carla Ingraham So if I wrote a traditional Japanese story in American 
English would that make it an American story?

That's in essence what you just said.
comments.author: fmlAllthetime

comments.text:
+Carla Ingraham You make a fair point about it not being strictly 
either/or, but I still have to take issue with the notion that he was 
"arrogant" at all. I think a modern reader from the developed world could 
well draw that conclusion, because in modern society anyone who would 
willingly fight is looked at as being somehow insane. In Beowulf's social 
context, however, he was doing exactly what was expected of him as a 
warrior-aristocrat. That, indeed, is really the whole purpose of the story: 
it's a demonstration of how the ideal warrior/aristocrat ought to behave. 
Beowulf is decisive, loyal, generous, and brave. Rightly proud of his 
abilities and status, perhaps, but "arrogant" is not the right word.
comments.author: Pete McKenna

comments.text:
It is set in Scandinavia but is classified as Anglo-Saxon literature 
because it was written in Old English in ENGLAND during the time of 
Germanic invasions. I teach British lit, and this is an anchor piece for 
Anglo-Saxon epic. Thanks for the geography lesson, though.
comments.author: Carla Ingraham

comments.text:
+rock starblow There is a lot of background in Anglo-Saxon tradition that 
emerges from the story.  What Sparky covers in rulership is a part of it, 
but the greater part is the comitatus (relationship between the king and 
thane) that is at the core of Beowulf's and Hrothgar's relationship, 
especially when Hrothgar's wife becomes concerned for her children's 
inheritance.  The giving king and loyal-unto-death vassals are challenged 
at the end when Beowulf's men flee from the dragon, and Beowulf dies 
because the system that they are to live by fails.  There is also the 
wergild (life-price or death-price) that entails a payment for causing the 
death of a kinsman (accidental or intentional); if the wergild is not paid, 
then vengeance is demanded.  This is why Hrothgar is a fallen king, he is 
powerless to exact the wergild from Grendel, this is why Grendel's 
mother comes to avenge his death, etc...   There is also a nationalist 
element in the story as Beowulf, a foreigner, comes to battle Grendel since 
none of the warriors there can handle the job, foreshadowing in the story 
of Sigmund and the dragon that alludes to Beowulf's battle with the dragon, 
rich inclusion of pagan Anglo-Saxon mythology and Christianity, and so much 
more!
comments.author: Carlos Ulivarri

comments.text:
Actually, the name Beowulf is a combination of Bee and hunter. Beo is bee 
in Old English, and Wulf can be Wolf but it can also mean hunter. Thus 
Bee-hunter, and what animal hunts after bees? A bear.

To say man-wolf is ǷER-ƿulf, hence the modern day Werewolf. Wer is man in 
Old English and Wulf in this case, would mean wolf.﻿

comments.text:
That is a tough question to answer... I have read tales that the story, or 
it's premise, is at least 3000 years old. The more common perception is it 
originated in the 7th century.  It was shared threw story tellers and hand 
down threw the generations of the Anglo and the Saxons until around the 
year 750 ad when 4 monks put it down on paper, in Old English, being sure 
to infuse christian ideals within.  The first translation in Modern English 
was done by Sharron Turner in 1805 ad.  Now there are hundreds of 
translations, Crossley-Holland's being one of my personal favorites. 
 J.R.R. Tolken just released his version earlier this year, I believe it 
was edited by his son.
comments.author: Benjamin rennels

seemed to work out for him.﻿

comments.author: Roland Guiscard

comments.text:
MOVIE SPOILERS
It was kind of a weird choice for the movie-makers to make Beowulf have sex 
with Grendels mother.  And the whole thing just felt uncomfortable to me. 
It being a Danish folk-tale and all. Why would you make him have sex with a 
demonic being, when the original tale had someone simply stealing some 
trinket from the dragon?﻿
comments.author: TheOnlyMonkeyDragon

comments.author: Brandon Molitor

comments.text:
I could have sworn Beowulf was a kenning for BEAR. Beo- bee, and wulf... is 
wolf (representing a predator). Or, simply put, a predator of bees. Bears 
were scary, scary things, and common superstition was that saying its 
actual name was to invoke its appearance...﻿

comments.author: Seamus MacMattain

comments.text:
Usually, I really dig these videos, but I disagreed with this analysis. The 
reason Beowulf falls in the end is because he has to. There has to be a 
fitting end to the story, with the hero embracing his own mortality after 
the great final battle (see Arthur v Mordred for more). I do not think it 
is fair to attribute some inner monstrosity to him. This is back in the day 
when a good sword hand was a very prized thing, after al...﻿
